awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How Recognizing Gaps in Explanations Influences Children's Interest in Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The ECR (Education and Human Resources Core Research) program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. The complex domain of biology has causal pathways that are not always readily apparent to young children, and their explanations often contain many misconceptions and gaps in understanding. This project will add to a limited body of research on how children's recognition of information gaps influence subsequent interest in learning in formal and informal learning settings. The project will examine to what extent, if any, receiving or producing explanations motivates children's future learning, with three specific goals: (1) to examine whether children who first recognize that an explanation has significant gaps are interested in engaging in further learning of a particular topic; (2) to explore how the source of the explanation (by self or others) relates to the link between recognizing information gaps and future learning; and (3) to develop instructional strategies that can be used to induce students' recognition of explanatory gaps, measuring outcomes for these strategies, including children's subsequent ability to critically evaluate explanations and their interest in future learning. The conceptual framework will be guided by the social-cognitive theory, sociocultural theory, and mechanistic reasoning. This combined theoretical framing will promote a better assessment of which processes drive children's explanation evaluation - a crucial part of learning from others - and how mechanistic explanations can be useful lenses for analyzing the interactions of domain-specific (prior knowledge) and domain-general knowledge about learning.

This project will use laboratory-based quantitative methods and classroom-based teaching experiments. The quantitative methods include ANCOVAs of multiple covariates about a model that will be developed and implemented to explain developmental, individual, and task differences in responses to information gaps in scientific explanations. Behavioral measures will include ratings of explanation quality and individual difference measures, such as self-reported interest, biological knowledge, and interest in acquiring new information. Based on results from laboratory studies, scaffolds will be developed for classroom contexts to support children's productive engagement in critically evaluating biological explanations. A subset of the above measures will be use to collect pre-post data from classroom participants. Conjecture mapping will be used to conceptualize specific links between scaffolds, mediating processes, and outcomes. Classroom video and observations will be used to determine the extent to which the design scaffolds lead to the hypothesized mediating processes and ultimately the desired learning outcomes of effective evaluation and generation of mechanistic explanations of biological phenomena. Outcomes from these studies will advance scientific understanding of young children's explanation evaluation and construction, as well as provide a suite of scaffolds to support effective education practice. Combining lab and classroom-based research will lead to the development of more ecologically-valid methodologies for studying, and impacting, learning behaviors in ways that are beneficial to interdisciplinary research and education. Insights from the research will be beneficial to parents, children and teachers in both formal and informal settings. Finally, the project will provide insight into creating developmentally-appropriate interventions to help determine whether children of a certain age might benefit from instruction focused on recognizing explanatory gaps in order to motivate them to seek out better answers.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated how children ages 7-10 reason about explanations of biological phenomena, how their reasoning changes over the course of development, and the factors that influence variability in children's reasoning. The first part of the project looked at how children evaluate incomplete or complete explanations to questions about animal behavior (e.g., How do some buffaloes keep insects from biting them?) and how receiving incomplete explanations relates to children's motivation to learn. We found that children recognized when they had received incomplete explanations, and that they were motivated to learn more about the incomplete explanations in some contexts. Children's explanation evaluation and motivation was also related to their biological knowledge and verbal skill.

The second part of the project looked at how children evaluate evidence for causal explanations of animal behaviors (e.g., an explanation that turtles stand up on their hind legs to scare away predators). We found that children ages 7-8 had more difficulty than children ages 9-10 in recognizing that observations of a different animal species engaging in a behavior involving the same causal mechanism (e.g., blowfish puff up to scare away predators) would be more helpful than observations of the same species engaging in a behavior involving a different mechanism (e.g., turtles prefer to live in muddy areas). 

The third part of the project took our findings from the lab to the classroom through a series of science activities designed for fourth grade students. These activities were designed to promote children's use of evidence to evaluate explanations. 

The project resulted in the development of two new tools for researchers: the Prompted Explanation Task (PET) and a brief biological knowledge measure for children ages 6-10. The PET is a brief experimental task designed to sample verbal explanations in a short period of time. A computer prompts participants to verbally respond to questions as if they were talking to a specific target (e.g., their own child), and responses are transcribed and coded. We found that how frequently parents provided correct responses to science questions on the PET predicted children's verbal intelligence and biological knowledge. We also found that parents varied in the characteristics of the explanations they provided, such as how often they referred to uncertainty. The brief biological knowledge measure pulls questions from the fourth grade life science sections of the Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study (TIMSS) to assess domain-specific knowledge in a short amount of time. We found that performance on this task related to children's assessment of explanations as well as to parents' own explanations of science. 

Our findings have been shared via 8 published manuscripts and multiple conference presentations. Undergraduate and graduate students also benefited from training in research design, data collection, and data analysis as part of the project. Findings from these studies will also be shared with teachers and other educators.
